statement.tex: \text{Write the vector equation of the plane, passing} \\ \text{through the point $(a, b, c)$ and parallel to the} \\ \text{plane }\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{1}{1}{1})=2

step.context: \text{For a plane whose equation is }\ora{r}\cdot \hat{n}=d \\ \text{$\hat{n}$ - unit vector normal to the plane} \\ \text{$d$ - $\perp$ distance from origin to the plane.} \\ \text{What are unit vector normal and $\perp$ distance} \\ \text{from origin, for the plane }\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{1}{1}{1})=2?

\text{If we were to{\bf push} (or pull) the plane} \\ \ora{r}\cdot(\vector{1}{1}{1})=2 \text{ such that the unit vector}\\ \text{normal to it remained the same, but the plane} \\ \text{passed through $(a, b, c)$. What would it's} \\ \text{equation look like now?}
step.reason: \text{$(a, b, c)$ is at a $\perp$ distance $\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}$} \\ \text{from the origin. Substituting this in the} \\ \text{equation of the equation of the plane,} \\ \ora{r}\cdot\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}}(\vector{1}{1}{1}) =\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}
